The methods employed were documentary analysis, observing meetings, a focus group, 2 student questionnaires, one-to-one interviews with staff and group and one-to-one interviews with South Asian female student teachers. It is argued that whilst social characteristics such as gender, language, religion and culture are important in determining notions of commonality and difference, a shared experience of racism between the researched and the researcher may affect the research relationship most significantly. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Resiliency and recovery: Lessons from the Asian tsunami and Hurricane Katrina.
Author: Fernando, Delini M.; Hebert, Barbara B.
Journal Title: Journal of Multicultural Counseling and Development
Subjects: Natural Disasters; Resilience (Psychological); Survivors; Trauma; Asians; Human Females
Abstract: Separated by continents and cultures, survivors of the Asian tsunami and Hurricane Katrina share a common bond in their extreme trauma and ensuing struggles. The authors discuss and illustrate core ideas based on the commonalities derived from the experiences of women survivors of these two disasters. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Resiliency mechanisms in culturally diverse families.
Author: Johnson, Alf C.
Subjects: Cross Cultural Differences; Family Relations; Interethnic Family; Resilience (Psychological); American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Mexican Americans; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Identified and discussed 10 resiliency mechanisms in culturally diverse families, including those of African-American, Mexican-American, Puerto Rican, American Indian, and Southeast Asian descent. Mechanisms include: (1) the metaphor of the sacred arc; (2) the bonds of kinship; (3) spiritual support; (4) the covenant with elders; (5) safety and refuge; (6) socialization and communication; (7) use of native language; (8) protection from racism; (9) the effects of migration; and (10) individual resiliency. These factors are guardians of the family's integrity that evolve as the family matures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Resisting from the margins: The coping strategies of Black women and other women of color faculty members at a research university.
Author: Thomas, Gloria D.; Hollenshead, Carol
Publisher: Assn of American University Presses/Howard University Press
Subjects: College Teachers; Coping Behavior; Human Females; Minority Groups; School Environment; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Social Support; Teacher Attitudes; Latinos/Latinas; Female
Abstract: This article argues that women of color, despite their marginalized position in the academy, need not consider their place as one of deprivation solely. In light of their considerable successes, a study was conducted to address 2 questions: How have academic women of color managed to cope, professionally and personally, given their marginalized position; and how have they used their position as a point and place of resistance to racism, sexism, and classism? Data were also collected from Latina, Asian, and Native American Faculty women. Secondary analyses of survey and interview data from faculty women of color at a major US research university revealed that these women's resistance strategies addressed 5 major areas: Organizational barriers, institutional climate, lack of respect from one's colleagues, unwritten rules governing university life, and mentoring. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Rethinking the value of choice: A cultural perspective on intrinsic motivation.
Author: Iyengar, Sheena S.; Lepper, Mark R.
Journal Title: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
Subjects: Choice Behavior; Culture (Anthropological); Intrinsic Motivation; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Asians; Whites; Childhood (birth-12 yrs); School Age (6-12 yrs); Male; Female
Abstract: Conventional wisdom and decades of psychological research have linked the provision of choice to increased levels of intrinsic motivation, greater persistence, better performance, and higher satisfaction. This investigation examined the relevance and limitations of these findings for cultures in which individuals possess more interdependent models of the self. In 2 studies, personal choice generally enhanced motivation more for American independent selves than for Asian interdependent selves. In addition, Anglo American children showed less intrinsic motivation when choices were made for them by others than when they made their own choices, whether the others were authority figures or peers. In contrast, Asian American children proved most intrinsically motivated when choices were made for them by trusted authority figures or peers. Theoretical and practical implications of these findings are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Diverse millennial students in college: Implications for faculty and student affairs.
Author: Park, Julie J.
Subjects: College Students; Colleges; Educational Personnel; Student Characteristics; Student Personnel Services; Asians; Blacks; Pacific Islanders; Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Abstract: Reviews the book, Diverse Millennial Students in College: Implications for Faculty and Student Affairs by Fred A. Bonner II, Aretha F. Marbley, and Mary F. Howard-Hamilton (Eds.) (2011). The term Millennial is often used to describe the cohort born in the early 1980s to late 1990s many of whom entered college following the year 2000. As numerous authors in this edited book point out, the very attempt to use a single term to capture an entire generation of students is inherently inadequate, given the vast diversity of the student population. Furthermore, the images and trends evoked by the Millennial label can fall short in showcasing the range of experiences between and within key student sub-populations. This edited volume seeks to remedy some of these issues by providing a more complex and nuanced depiction of the diversity of the Millennial generation. Chapter 1 discusses assumptions about Millennial. Chapters 2 and 3 provide two perspectives on Black Millennial students. Chapters 4 and 5 address facets of experiences related to Asian American and Pacific Islander Millennials, although the chapters focus more on Asian American rather than Pacific Islander students. In chapter 6, the authors use data from the UCLA Higher Education Research Institute's Cooperative Institutional Research Program to compare cohorts of Latino/a Millennials over the generations. Chapter 10 overviews key issues related to LGBTQ Millenials. Chapter 13 focuses more specifically on how different Millennial traits may manifest themselves among multiracial students, as well as the issues of peer culture, identity politics, and academic interests. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Acculturation: Advances in theory, measurement, and applied research.
Author: Levy, Jacob J.
Subjects: Acculturation; Experimentation; Measurement; Minority Groups; Theories; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: This reviewed book (originally covered in record [rid]2002-18425-000[/rid]) addresses issues of international acculturation (e.g. examining the generational patterns of Latino and Asian individuals and families as they acculturate to life in the United States and Canada), as well as intra-national acculturation (e.g. examining the nature of American Indian and African American acculturation and identity development, as they face the challenges of living in a White dominated culture). It is important to note that the book focuses on acculturating into American (and to some extent Canadian) culture. Although some of the themes in the book may be relevant for a global readership (for example, the impact differences in language, religion, and social status have on the ability to acculturate), the majority of research presented is limited to minority populations of the United States and Canada, specifically people from Asian decent, Latinos, African Americans, and to a lesser degree American Indians. The book is comprised of four parts, which take the reader from a conceptual understanding of acculturation, including an overview of relevant research, to a more applied focus in the latter chapters of the text. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Acculturation: Advances in Theory, Measurement, and Applied Research.
Author: Westermeyer, Joseph
Journal Title: Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease
Subjects: Acculturation; Experimentation; Measurement; Minority Groups; Theories; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Reviews the book 'Acculturation: Advances in theory, measurement, and applied research,' edited by Kelvin M. Chun, Pamela B. Organista and Geraldo Marin (see record [rid]2002-18425-000[/rid]). Six of the 11 chapters concentrate on normal dimensions of acculturation from psychological perspectives. Their topics cover general concepts, psychometric challenges, identity, values, and family. The last five chapters encompass health psychology and abnormal psychology from an acculturation perspective. These chapters are more data-focused, with 12 tables and only one figure of a model of health and illness. Some chapters address enculturation for minority groups rather than acculturation, although these authors use the term acculturation rather than enculturation. This book should prove interesting and perhaps helpful to several groups of psychiatrists. Those working with immigrants, refugees, and internal migrants (e.g., rural-to-urban migrants) will confirm many of their clinical hunches and perhaps broaden their conceptual horizons regarding migration and its concomitants. Cultural psychiatrists early in their careers will find the volume an excellent entree to recent work on acculturation, particularly the work performed by cultural psychologists. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Age, Narrative and Migration. The Life Course and Life Histories of Bengali Elders in London.
Author: Krause, Inga-Britt
Subjects: Immigration; Life Experiences; Narratives; Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; Asians; Whites; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Aged (65 yrs & older)
Abstract: In the author's second major work on the Sylheti Bangladeshi community, she concentrates on those Sylhetis who are resident in London and who arrived some time ago, mostly to seek work or in order to accompany relatives who sought work. These Sylhetis are now elders and have a unique outlook not only on the relationship between themselves and the indigeneous White population, but also on their own lives. The book deserves to be read by those health professionals who work with the elderly and those who work with families because it will help them provide equitable and non-discriminatory health care. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Appropriately Indian: Gender and culture in a new transnational class.
Author: Talukdar, Jaita
Subjects: Computer Software; Cross Cultural Differences; Multinational Corporations; Sex Roles; Information and Communication Technology; Asians; Economics; Engineers; Globalization; Organizations; Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Abstract: Reviews the book, Appropriately Indian: Gender and Culture in a New Transnational Class by Smitha Radhakrishnan (2011). This book presents an argument about the idea of an economically powerful and culturally robust India rides on the backs of a relatively small group of information technology (IT) professionals in the country. The data for this book are based on an ethnographic, multisite study of the lives of Indian IT professionals, primarily engineers, working in software and hardware sectors in India and the United States. The author is at her best when she shows that for IT professionals protecting the family actually means preserving gender roles and family arrangements that constitute their privileged backgrounds. This book is a strong rebuttal to the popular argument that neoliberal economic policies have opened the doors of opportunity for all. Instead it offers important insights into how local cultures and internal hierarchies shape the nature of cultural and economic globalization. The only dissatisfying part of the book was the section on religion. The reader has to wait to find out that a key concern of the book is examining how Hindu ideologies impact the transnational class, which in the end is subjected to only a few pages of analysis. Nevertheless, this is an exceptionally well written and theoretically rich book that will be a great addition to graduate and upper-level undergraduate courses on transnationalism, globalization, culture, development, sociological theories, or South Asian studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Baby Boomers of color: Implications for social work policy and practice.
Author: Mitchell, Jamie A.
Subjects: Aging; Intergenerational Relations; Minority Groups; Positive Psychology; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Health Service Needs; Pacific Islanders; Psychological Needs; Social Casework; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Reviews the book, Baby Boomers of Color: Implications for Social Work Policy and Practice by M. Delgado (see record [rid]2014-48850-000[/rid]). Baby Boomers of Color highlights the unique cultural and biopsychosocial needs of African American, Asian/Pacific Islander, Latino, and Native American/Alaskan Native elders from a distinct social work perspective. In the opening chapters, Melvin Delgado utilizes data on population demographics to frame a broad but thorough discussion on financial well-being, health care access and quality, and affordable housing for elders of color, while addressing the ongoing debate over the economic impact of an aging baby boomer generation on the Social Security and Medicare systems in the United States. Baby Boomers of Color seems to target social work clinicians and researchers but has wide applicability and value for other health and social care professionals who serve diverse older adults. Each chapter is filled with salient and timely information regarding the current trends across a variety of aspects for boomers of color while highlighting known interventions for addressing the socioeconomic and health disadvantages that are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Cultural issues in play therapy.
Author: McGeorge, Christine R.
Subjects: Cultural Sensitivity; Knowledge Level; Play Therapy; Professional Competence; Sociocultural Factors; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Chinese Cultural Groups; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Reviews the book, Cultural issues in play therapy by Eliana Gil and Athena A. Drewes (see record [rid]2005-02803-000[/rid]). Drs. Gil and Drewes, along with several wonderful collaborators, have created a new book that fills an important void in the play therapy literature. The book is divided into two parts: (1) 'Background and General Considerations,' and (2) 'Play Therapy with Major Cultural Groups.' The first section of the book begins by introducing a model of cross-cultural competence that is broken down into three separate steps or levels: (1) building sensitivity, (2) obtaining knowledge, and (3) developing active competence. The second section of the book is focused on play therapy with four different larger cultural groups: (1) African Americans, (2) Latinos, (3) Native Americans, and (4) Asians, with a particular emphasis on Chinese culture. I am currently enjoying using this book in my graduate course on play therapy and would recommend this book to other educators and play therapists. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Culturally contested pedagogy: Battles of literacy and schooling between mainstream teachers and Asian immigrant parents.
Author: Wamba, Nathalis G.
Journal Title: Reading & Writing Quarterly: Overcoming Learning Difficulties
Subjects: Cultural Sensitivity; Language Arts Education; Sociocultural Factors; Teaching Methods; Asians; Conflict; Immigration
Abstract: Reviews the book Culturally contested pedagogy: Battles of literacy and schooling between mainstream teachers and Asian immigrant parents, by Guofang Li (2006). In this book the author investigated the relationships between seven Chinese-Canadian families, eight Chinese-Canadian students, and two Euro-Canadian teachers at the Taylor Elementary School in Richmond, a predominantly middle-class Chinese neighborhood in the greater Vancouver area. Her findings revealed cultural clashes and symbolic struggles between Euro-Canadian teachers and Chinese-Canadian immigrant parents. The conflicts centered on the school's methods of literacy instruction. The Chinese-Canadian parents preferred traditional, teacher-centered, code-emphasis education. Li saw the conflict between Euro-Canadian teachers and Chinese-Canadian parents through the narrow prism of culture. Consequently, her solution was culturally sensitive pedagogy. Although it has merit, it is too narrow to solve the problem. To solve the problem, the solution must go beyond this. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Diversity in Counseling.
Author: Stills, Aaron B.; Harper, Frederick D.
Journal Title: International Journal for the Advancement of Counselling
Subjects: Cross Cultural Counseling; Cross Cultural Differences; Feminism; Lesbianism; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Asians; Blacks; Counseling; Ethnic Identity; Minority Groups
Abstract: Reviews the book 'Diversity in Counseling,' by R. Brammer (2004). The book is divided into four main parts that contain a total of 11 chapters. Part I includes one chapter as an introduction to diversity. Part II has five chapters on the major traditional ethnic groups in the USA; 'African Americans, Latin Americans, Asian Americans, Native Americans, and European Americans.' Part III's four chapters address 'Gays and Lesbians,' 'Transgendered Persons,' 'Women and Feminism,' and 'Men and the Men's Movement.' The final division, Part IV, has only one chapter on the subject of 'Mixed Cultural Identities.' In addition, the book provides discussions on the family within the context of culture, historical oppression, health, education, and, of course, counseling strategies from a cultural and/or diversity perspective. In general, the book is a resourceful and stimulating textbook that addresses a broad array of issues and topics as related to culture and diversity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Ethnicity and substance abuse: Prevention and intervention.
Author: Flynn, William R.
Subjects: Drug Abuse; Drug Abuse Prevention; Minority Groups; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Treatment; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Sociocultural Factors; Latinos/Latinas; Substance Use Treatment
Abstract: Reviews the book 'Ethnicity and Substance Abuse: Prevention and Intervention' by Grace Xueqin Ma and George Henderson (see record [rid]2003-02439-000[/rid]). The first section is devoted to concepts of addiction, crosscultural communication, and social ecology. The addiction concepts are familiar ones, and the essence of the chapter on cross-cultural communication is that it is important for care providers to understand the culture of their designated patients. The book as a whole is as much about the consequences of poverty relating to drug abuse as it is about the role that minority status plays. The focus of the book is on describing the experiences that the authors and other workers had while working with and studying substance abuse in different ethnic groups. They include substantial reviews of the relevant literature. The reviewer believes that this work will be of interest to workers in any of the disciplines involved in treating chemical dependency. Although the concepts are basic to psychiatry, there is considerable information presented here, by and large in the form of data and statistics on the prevalence of the different forms of abuse in the several ethnic populations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Family violence in a cultural perspective: Defining, understanding, and combating abuse.
Author: Logan, T. K.
Subjects: Child Abuse; Domestic Violence; Elder Abuse; Intimate Partner Violence; Racial and Ethnic Differences; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Reviews the book, Family violence in a cultural perspective: Defining, understanding, and combating abuse by Kathleen Malley-Morrison and Denise Hines (2004). This book examines factors and research around child abuse, spouse abuse, and elder abuse in the U.S. for Native American Indian cultures, African American cultures, Hispanic/Latino cultures, and Asian American cultures. The book concludes with chapters on prevention and interventions for child and adult maltreatment. One unique feature of this book that would be particularly useful for students, are the interesting case studies sprinkled throughout each chapter as well as questions for thought also sprinkled throughout each chapter. This book approaches the topics by helping the reader understand how implicit theories drive interpretations of behavior or situations and decision making. The book also helps the reader to begin to understand his or her implicit theories about certain situations and asks the reader to consider how different cultural contexts may influence interpretations of various situations. The end product of this book is that it is very readable and thought provoking. It would be useful especially for undergraduate students or others interested in culture, as it provides a valuable overview of child, spouse, and elder abuse in the U.S., and in these areas in the above mentioned cultures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Freud and the far east—Psychoanalytic perspectives on the people and culture of China, Japan and Korea.
Author: Alfonso, César A.
Journal Title: Journal of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis & Dynamic Psychiatry
Subjects: Cross Cultural Differences; Psychoanalysis; Psychoanalytic Theory; Transcultural Psychiatry; Asians; Freud (Sigmund)
Abstract: Reviews the book, Freud and the far east—Psychoanalytic perspectives on the people and culture of China, Japan and Korea edited by Salman Akhta and Jason Aronson (see record [rid]2009-12182-000[/rid]). This edited book contains 17 essays by distinguished scholars who have dedicated their careers to the study of transcultural aspects of psychoanalytic theory and technique. Each essay can stand by itself as an invaluable contribution to our understanding of the cultures of Japan, Korea and China, and of the relevance of the cultural complexity of these countries and their people in our clinical work. Freud and the Far East gives us a glimpse of the complexities and richness of Asian cultures and experience. Freud and the Far East is a magnificent book in that it is both encyclopedic without being too dense or too superficial, and invites readers to become curious about our cultural differences and similarities. I applaud the editor and authors for their important contributions to the field of transcultural psychoanalysis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Language policy, culture, and identity in Asian contexts.
Author: Hu, Guangwei
Subjects: Culture (Anthropological); Ethnic Identity; Globalization; Language; Policy Making; Asians; Economy; English as Second Language; Ethnolinguistics; Politics; Social Issues
Abstract: Reviews the book, Language policy, culture, and identity in Asian contexts by Amy Tsui and James Tollefson (see record [rid]2006-21012-000[/rid]). This an edited volume that focuses on such relationships in 12 Asian societies differing widely in terms of economic, political, and sociocultural development. The book is comprised of a preface and 14 chapters. One strength is its inclusion of a range of Asian countries that differ in sociopolitical contexts. A second strength is the insider's perspective provided by each chapter on each of the Asian societies presented. Finally, the chapters collectively present a rich and textured narrative that captures complex patterns and contradictory trends in the intricate intertwining of language, culture and identity in Asian contexts. There are a couple of downsides to the book as well. First, several chapters are devoid of analyses grounded in a theory of language policy and identity. Second, there is the conspicuous omission of mainland China. The book is a timely and invaluable addition to the scholarship on globalisation, language planning and policy, culture and identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Minor re/visions: Asian American literacy narratives as a rhetoric of citizenship, Reading Chinese fortune cookie: The making of Chinese American rhetoric, and Representations: Doing Asian American rhetoric.
Author: Summers, Sarah
Journal Title: Journal of Language, Identity, and Education
Subjects: Chinese Cultural Groups; Citizenship; Literacy; Rhetoric; Asians; Narratives; Reading
Abstract: Reviews the books, Minor re/visions: Asian American literacy narratives as a rhetoric of citizenship by M. Young (2004); Reading Chinese fortune cookie: The making of Chinese American rhetoric edited by L. Mao (2006) and Representations: Doing Asian American rhetoric by L. Mao & M. Young (2008). These three books present a way of understanding the process by which specific rhetorical practices become identified, named, and applied. While the move from narrating and making to doing does suggest a chronological trajectory, it is important to realize that the project these books encompass is not solely linear. Rather, these books inhabit a recursive space in which each project informs and revises the other. Representations does not suggest an end or culmination of the work on Asian American rhetoric. Instead, these works provide multiple entry points for upcoming works that will extend our already rich understandings of Asian American rhetorical practices and their influence on and creative resistance of dominant rhetoric. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Minority and Cross Cultural Aspects of Neuropsychological Assessment.
Author: Young, Susan
Subjects: Cross Cultural Differences; Minority Groups; Neuropsychological Assessment; American Indians; Arabs; Asians; Blacks; Pacific Islanders; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: This book by F. R. Ferraro (see record [rid]2002-02380-000[/rid]) reviews the current literature on ethnic and cultural issues in neurological assessment and includes chapters that focus on traditions and trends in clinical neuropsychology. The need for the development of culturally relevant norms is increasingly evident in our multicultural society and overall the book explores the limitations of neuropsychological assessment tools across a wide range of minority groups and populations. The book is topical and informative and strives to report how colleagues across the world are rising to the challenge of assessing neurocognition in culturally diverse populations. There is a strong focus on service provision and the book introduces the reader to newly established contemporaneous cross-cultural neuropsychological instruments and provides norms for individual minority groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Minority and Cross-Cultural Aspects of Neuropsychological Assessment.
Author: Byrd, Desiree
Journal Title: Journal of Clinical and Experimental Neuropsychology
Subjects: Cross Cultural Differences; Minority Groups; Neuropsychological Assessment; Aging; American Indians; Arabs; Asians; Blacks; Pacific Islanders; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Reviews the book 'Minority and Cross-Cultural Aspects of Neuropsychological Assessment,' edited by Richard Ferraro (see record [rid]2002-02380-000[/rid]). This book helps fill the great cross-cultural void in neuropsychology by providing a synopsis of current research on the science and practice of neuropsychology in a cross-cultural context. More importantly, this book expands the common conception of diversity beyond African-American and Hispanic culture. For the first time in a neuropsychology text, data on Native Americans, Guamanians, Japanese, and Saudi Arabians are presented alongside that of traditional American minority groups. contains twenty chapters organized into four sections specific to ethnic group affiliations (i.e., African-Americans, Asian/Pacific Islanders (Japan/Guam), Hispanic/Latino, and Native Americans), one mixed section (Rural populations/Elderly/Saudi Arabians) and the last sections devoted to future directions in the field. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Muslim education in the 21st century: Asian perspectives.
Author: Hefner, Robert W.
Subjects: Education; Muslims; Teaching; Asians
Abstract: Reviews the book, Muslim Education in the 21st Century: Asian Perspectives edited by Sa'eda Buang and Phyllis Ghim-Lian Chew (2014). Sa'eda Buang and Phyllis Ghim-Lian Chew's volume on Muslim education in Asia falls largely within the second of these two types of research. As the editors state in their introduction, the volume aims to transcend the 'continuing … 'popular'angle of seeing the Muslim school as an object of contempt or a cradle of and for contentions'. In fact, and to the volume's credit, several of the chapters do touch on the role of Islamic schooling in politics and social contention. Nonetheless the editors have set an estimable aim in setting out to explore 'whether and how the Muslim school has reinvented itself in the field of pedagogy and curriculum to meet the challenges of 21st century education'. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Promoting a good death for cancer patients of Asian culture. An evidence-based approach.
Author: Yu, Juping
Subjects: Evidence Based Practice; Neoplasms; Nursing; Social Services; Asians; Death and Dying
Abstract: Reviews the book, Promoting a good death for cancer patients of Asian culture. An evidence-based approach by M. H. J. Mak (2007). The book is well organized and the reference list for each chapter is useful. It is also well written and easy to read, which makes it accessible not only to researchers, academics and health professionals, but also to students across various disciplines, such as medicine, nursing and social care, although the cost of GBP42 is somewhat expensive. I would recommend this book to anyone who wishes to understand cultural perspectives, Chinese culture in particular, on death and dying. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Race and family: A structural approach.
Author: Rollings-Magnusson, Sandra
Subjects: Family Relations; Family Structure; Family; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Parenting; American Indians; Asians; Blacks; Latinos/Latinas
Abstract: Reviews the book, Race and family: A structural approach by Roberta L. Coles (2006). This textbook, written primarily for American students at the college or university level, offers insights into contemporary American culture, provides an interesting perspective with regard to how family issues are studied, places importance on historical factors, and draws attention to the diversity found in American society in terms of racial and ethnic differences. I believe that the greatest strength of this book is the thorough discussion that the author has provided of four particular racial groups found in the United States—African Americans, Native Americans, Latino Americans and Asian Americans. In each chapter, the author highlights the historical development of each group, their social expectations relating to family life, and their most common family structure. She also provides a selection of demographics and points out unique trends and characteristics associated with each racial group. It is a book that is well written, includes a substantial amount of detail with up-to-date statistics, presents relevant examples, and at the end of each chapter includes appealing suggestions for additional reading materials, videos and websites. The only difficulty that I have with this book is that it relies too heavily on using only one perspective—the structural approach. While this perspective is fairly broad in scope by including economic, demographic, and historical-legal factors, I believe that this book would benefit greatly by incorporating theories relating to feminism, and/or to power, domination and exploitation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Racing romance: Love, power, and desire among Asian American/White couples.
Author: Le Espiritu, Yen
Subjects: Couples; Love; Romance; Desire; Asians; Interethnic Family; Society; Whites; Interpersonal Control
Abstract: Reviews the book, Racing romance: Love, power, and desire among Asian American/White couples by Kumiko Nemoto (2009). The author describes the book as less a collection of 'love stories' between Asian Americans and whites than a collection of stories about discourses of love and power in contemporary American society. According to Nemoto, most white men filter their relationships with Asian women through a lens of color-blindness and multiculturalism, in which the race of their partner is understood as a matter of culture and appearance and the increase in intermarriage is heralded as evidence of America’s racial progress. The insight here is that seemingly private emotions, such as desire, anxiety, and repulsion, are deeply gendered and racialized. This is where the book does not quite deliver. Although Nemoto emphasizes that interracial romance is constituted by and constitutive of gendered, sexualized, and racialized discourses and practices that circulate between Asia and the United States, this critical stance is not tightly grafted to the respondents’ personal narratives. This book gives not only an unfinished feel, but also de-contextualizes and de-historicizes these life stories, making it difficult to grasp the connection between desire, social structure, and power that Nemoto clearly wants us to see. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Sexual cultures in East Asia: The social construction of sexuality and sexual risk in a time of AIDS.
Author: Ingham, Roger
Subjects: AIDS; Culture (Anthropological); Sexual Risk Taking; Sexuality; Sociocultural Factors; Asians; Constructivism; Culture Change; Modernization; Prostitution; Sexually Transmitted Diseases; Traditions; Values
Abstract: Reviews 'Sexual cultures in East Asia: The social construction of sexuality and sexual risk in a time of AIDS' (2004). This book arises mainly from papers presented at the International Institute for Asian Studies conference held in Amsterdam in 2000. The authors are a mix of social and medical anthropologists, historians, sociologists, communication specialists, medical doctors and a development expert, with a good mix of Europeans and East Asians; the various papers report the results of a three-year research project funded by the European Science Foundation. The first part of the book deals with Sexual cultures: caught between traditions and transitions, with chapters on sex work of one kind or another in China, Japan, Vietnam and Cambodia. The chapters illustrate very well the value of a detailed understanding of what drives sex work, as well as how changes in such activity provide some insights into the impact of globalization in these countries. The second part of the collection--The social construction of sexual risk in the light of STDs/AIDS control--contains chapters on Republican Shanghai, Taiwan and Vietnam. Whilst all the chapters in this volume are of great interest, and raise issues of conflict between traditional values and modern changes, the final chapter is, in my view, the most provocative. Wolffers et al. disentangle the notion of traditional 'cultural' values, and present a powerful and cogent case that such values serve to privilege men in many Asian societies. If I have a criticism of the volume, it is that this fundamental issue is not discussed further. Given that the chapters emanate from a coordinated research programme, and many were presented at a conference, then I would like to have read rather more about the discussions between the participants, especially since they are drawn from both the West and the East. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of Sport and South Asian diasporas: Playing through time and space.
Author: Ratna, Aarti
Journal Title: International Review for the Sociology of Sport
Subjects: Mass Media; Sociologists; Sports; Asians; Films
Abstract: Reviews the book, Sport and South Asian Diasporas: Playing through Time and Space by Stanley Thangaraj, Daniel Burdsey & Rajinder Dudrah (2014). This book was originally published as a special issue in the journal South Asian Popular Culture. In their opening introduction, the editors are quick to dismiss the notion that sport and being South Asian do not mix. They argue that the spaces and practices of sport are, and have always been, important features of South Asian identities and cultural pastimes. Central to the editors’ understanding of sport and being South Asian is the concept of diaspora. key strength of this book is that the relationship between sport and being South Asian is never taken-for-granted. Many of the chapters in this book focus upon how sport is represented in and through popular cultural forms such as films, books, advertising and various media outlets. This book is a must read for sociologists of sport and more broadly, scholars of South Asian studies, theorists of race, ethnicity and gender, mass media and cultural studies researchers and writers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of The Family System Test (FAST). Theory and application.
Author: Meyer, Florence
Journal Title: Swiss Journal of Psychology / Schweizerische Zeitschrift für Psychologie / Revue Suisse de Psychologie
Subjects: Family Structure; Family Systems Theory; Measurement; Methodology; Psychometrics; Asians; Family Therapy; Testing
Abstract: Reviews the book, The Family System Test (FAST). Theory and application by T. M. Gehring, M. Debry, and P. K. Smith (2001). The FAST assesses family systems along the dimensions of family cohesion and family hierarchy. Gehring et al have arranged 17 chapters into 5 thematic groups: 1) Understanding family structures: Theory, assessment, and methodology; 2) Interpersonal patterns in non-clinical family systems; 3) the FAST in Asian cultures; 4) Clinical issues: A therapeutic tool for interactive assessment and treatment in family psychotherapy; and 5) Conclusions and recommendations. The review focuses on the first two sections. The first section describes the psychometric properties of the FAST, explains the science behind the instrument, and compares it to other competing instruments. Section 2 focuses on the use of the FAST with non-clinical groups to identify different qualities of family systems, a process that accounts for the influence of multiple variables. The only limitation observed by the reviewer was in the limited presentation and analysis of individual cases. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of The Hearing of Primitive Peoples.
Author: Starch, Daniel
Subjects: Auditory Acuity; Auditory Perception; Blacks; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Whites; Asians; Auditory Thresholds; South Asian Cultural Groups; Southeast Asian Cultural Groups
Abstract: Reviews the book, The Hearing of Primitive Peoples by F. G. Bruner (see record [rid]1908-10237-000[/rid]). In this monograph are presented the results of an interesting investigation to compare the hearing of several races in respect to two problems, namely, the upper threshold of pitch and simple acuity to sound. The investigation was made at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in 1904. Nearly four hundred individuals were tested who were distributed among different races as follows: 156 Whites, 63 Indians from the Government School, 137 Filipinos, 10 Cocopa Indians, 7 Ainu, 7 Vancouver Indians, 6 African Pigmies, and 4 Patagonian Indians. This monograph is valuable for the critical survey of previous investigations on the two problems studied and for the comparative data of the different races. The results of the three large groups (Whites, Indians, Filipinos) can be accepted with considerable confidence. Too few representatives of the other peoples were available to make the results final. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of The new CEOs: Women, African American, Latino, and Asian American leasers of Fortune 500 companies.
Author: Higginbotham, Elizabeth
Subjects: Business Organizations; Diversity in the Workplace; Industrialization; Top Level Managers; Transformational Leadership; Asians; Blacks; Latinos/Latinas; Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Abstract: Reviews the book, The New CEOs: Women, African American, Latino, and Asian American Leasers of Fortune 500 Companies by Richard L. Zweigenhaft and G. William Domhoff (2011). This book focuses on major corporate leaders, positions that have changed in this age of advanced industrialization. It includes a study of 74 business leaders, continue their investigation, to show the diversity and inclusion in the power elite. Secondary data to compile important demographics on the women, Latinos, African-Americans, and Asian Americans who have led major publicly traded corporations have been used. The authors draw on other research on leadership trends to place their stories in a context. While this new business era is characterized by a culture that rejects internal labor markets in search of charismatic leaders who can shake up companies, these women and racial-minority CEOs are more likely to be insiders who have proven themselves and are familiar with corporations before their selection by a board of directors. This book is sobering in how to shows us what many African-Americans corporate executives routinely say to each other about their corporations: 'Much has changed, but much as stayed the same'. The authors however need to get past the distractions and accept how this limited diversity has not really moved us forward as a nation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2018 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Review of White British researchers and internationally educated research participants: Insights from reflective practices on issues of language and culture in nursing contexts.
Author: Connor, Jorgia
Subjects: Ethnic Identity; Methodology; Minority Groups; Nurses; Qualitative Methods; Asians; Blacks; Cross Cultural Differences; Nursing; Race and Ethnic Discrimination; Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Abstract: Comments on White British researchers and internationally educated research participants: Insights from reflective practices on issues of language and culture in nursing contexts by Helen T. Allan and Sue Westwood (see record [rid]2015-56999-002[/rid]). This paper provides insight into methodological issues that occur in cross-cultural research. Reflexivity is an important strategy to use when conducting qualitative studies, particularly one in which the researchers and study participants are from different racial and ethnic backgrounds. The authors, who were white British researchers, conducted a qualitative study (focus groups) to explore the experiences of internationally educated nurses working as healthcare assistants in the NHS as part of a programme to increase pathways to UK registration. The authors provide an example of how they used reflexive practice in order to appraise critically the qualitative data that they gathered in order to curtail bias and misinterpretation. The two researchers presented their reflective discussions as they worked through the tensions that arose during their analysis. The authors' goal was to enhance the accuracy of the research and the credibility of their findings by engaging themselves consciously and deliberately to think about how their own experiences and values may have impacted their interpretations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Romance across the social status continuum: Interracial marriage and the ideological asymmetry effect.
Author: Fang, Carolyn Y.; Sidanius, Jim; Pratto, Felicia
Subjects: Interracial Marriage; Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Socioeconomic Class Attitudes; Social Status; Asians; Blacks; Whites; Latinos/Latinas; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: Examined the asymmetrical relationship between attitudes toward interracial marriage and social dominance orientation across 4 ethnic groups in the US. Differences in these correlations were explained with the ideological asymmetry hypothesis, a specific feature of social dominance theory, which asserts that the relationship between attitudes regarding hierarchy-maintaining social practices and antiegalitarian social values will be more positive among members of high-status groups than among members of low-status groups. Ss were 618 Euro-Americans, 475 Hispanics, 282 Asian Americans, and 474 Blacks. Using opposition to interracial marriage and dating as a case of a hierarchy-maintaining social attitude, the data were found to support the ideological asymmetry hypothesis. With almost no exceptions, the correlations between social dominance orientation and antimiscegenation attitudes were significantly more positive within a high-status ethnic group vis-a-vis a given low-status ethnic group than they were within a low-status ethnic group vis-a-vis a given high-status ethnic group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Roommate satisfaction and ethnic identity in mixed-race and White university roommate dyads.
Author: Phelps, Rosemary E.; Altschul, Deborah B.; Wisenbaker, Joseph M.; Day, James F.; Cooper, Diane; Potter, Carol G.
Subjects: Ethnic Identity; Peer Relations; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Roommates; Satisfaction; Asians; Blacks; Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; Whites; Latinos/Latinas; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs); Male; Female
Abstract: Examined roommate satisfaction and ethnic identity using the Roommate Relationship Inventory, the Ethnicity Questionnaire, and the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure in 54 African-American–White, 37 Asian-American–White, 11 Hispanic-American–White, and 48 White randomly assigned roommate dyads at a large, public, predominantly White, Southeastern university. White roommate dyads had significantly higher roommate satisfaction scores than African-American–White roommate dyads. Racial composition of roommate dyads, ethnic pride, and other-group orientation were significant predictors of roommate satisfaction. The authors also discuss implications for practice and suggestions for future research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: 'Sasaengpaen' or K-pop fan? Singapore youths, authentic identities, and Asian media fandom.
Author: Williams, J. Patrick; Ho, Samantha Xiang Xin
Subjects: Korean Cultural Groups; Popular Culture; Social Identity; Asians; Mass Media
Abstract: Since the late 1990s, the Korean pop-culture wave has had a huge impact, achieving immense popularity and sustaining a global community of consumers and fans. In Singapore, a significant K-pop fan culture has emerged among youths. In this article, we study the emergence of the sasaeng fan—a stigmatized fan identity that refers to individuals who are unhealthily interested in the personal lives of K-pop idols. Drawing on data from mass and social media, participant-observation, and interviews, we map the significance of the sasaeng fan identity for Singapore K-pop music fans and focus specific attention on how fans negotiate an understanding of their own 'authentic' identities vis-à-vis the mediated identity of the sasaeng fan. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Scared to death?
Author: Smith, Gary
Subjects: Chance (Fortune); Death and Dying; Mortality Rate; Numbers (Numerals); Sociocultural Factors; Asians; Cross Cultural Differences; Whites
Abstract: Conducted a test to compare deaths on the third, fourth, and fifth days of each month. California's computerized mortality records inclue the racial status recorded on death certificates. Of the Chinese-American and Japanese-American deaths on days 3, 4, and 5, 34% occurred on Day 4. If the number 4 affected mortality, we should find similar effects with other lucky and unlucky numbers. In Chinese culture number 7 can signify death, whereas White Americans generally consider 7 to be lucky; White Americans consider 13 to be unlucky, while the luckiest Chinese number is 8. Results reveal that none of the suggested days (4,7,8, and 13) was statistically persuasive. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: School violence in taiwan: Examining how western risk factors predict school violence in an asian culture.
Author: Chen, Ji-Kang; Astor, Ron Avi
Subjects: Risk Factors; School Environment; School Violence; Asians; Countries; Victimization; Childhood (birth-12 yrs); School Age (6-12 yrs); Adolescence (13-17 yrs); Male; Female
Abstract: The current study explores whether theorized risk factors in Western countries can be used to predict school violence perpetration in an Asian cultural context. The study examines the associations between risk factors and school violence perpetration in Taiwan. Data were obtained from a nationally representative sample of 14,022 students from elementary to high school (Grades 4 to 12) across Taiwan. The analysis reported in this study focuses on only junior high school students (Grades 7 to 9, N = 3,058). The results of a regression analysis show that gender, age, direct victimization, witness victimization, alcohol use, smoking, anger traits, lack of impulse control, attitudes toward violence, poor quality of student—teacher relationships, and involvement with at-risk peers were significantly associated with school violence in Taiwan. The overall results suggest strong similarities in risk factors found in the West and school violence in Taiwan. They therefore point toward using similar strategies developed in the West to enhance students’ positive experiences in their personal, family, and school lives to decrease school violence. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: School-based mental health prevention for Asian American adolescents: Risk behaviors, protective factors, and service use.
Author: Anyon, Yolanda; Ong, Seow Ling; Whitaker, Kelly
Subjects: Mental Health; Prevention; Racial and Ethnic Differences; School Based Intervention; Health Disparities; Asians; Protective Factors; Risk Factors; Adolescence (13-17 yrs); Male; Female
Abstract: This study drew on epidemiological data from a large urban school district to evaluate the implementation of a school-based mental health (SBMH) prevention initiative at 15 high schools. The purpose of this research was to measure the prevalence of student risk factors and protective factors by race and ethnicity and assess the engagement of Asian youth in prevention services. Results indicated statistically significant racial and ethnic group differences in the prevalence of risk factors (self-reported depressive symptoms, substance use, externalizing behavior at school, failing grades, truancy, and discrimination by school adults and peers), and protective factors (school, home, and peer assets). Controlling for gender, family structure, risk behaviors, protective factors, and school composition, Black (OR = 2.31, p < .001), Latino (OR = 1.36, p < .05), and multiracial (OR = 1.42, p < .01) students had significantly higher odds of using their SBMH program than Asian students. Among Asian ethnic subgroups, Cambodian youth (OR = .62, p < .01), were the only group that had lower odds of accessing school-based services than their Chinese peers. Findings suggest that, to reach underserved Asian American adolescents, prevention programs must address cultural and contextual influences on adolescent help seeking when program outreach and enrollment strategies are being developed. Additional research in the field of prevention science is needed to understand the mechanisms driving patterns of prevention service use by race and ethnicity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Science self-concept and valuing science: A cross-cultural analysis of their relation among students from Western and East Asian countries.
Author: Schütte, Kerstin
Journal Title: Social Psychology of Education: An International Journal
Subjects: Cross Cultural Differences; Science Education; Self-Concept; Student Characteristics; Ability; Asians; Countries; Motivation; Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Abstract: Devaluing an academic domain is a potential means of alleviating the psychological discomfort that results from the inconsistency of a low domain-specific self-concept of ability and great value attached to the domain. Such motivated devaluation of a domain is expected to be stronger in cultural contexts that promote a relatively greater focus on striving for a unique and consistent self than on the fulfillment of relevant others’ expectations. Moreover, motivated devaluation is expected to be stronger the closer the value construct is tied to the self. Multiple group structural equation models tested whether students’ self-concepts of their science ability differentially predicted the values students attach to science in Western and East Asian subsamples of the Programme for International Student Assessment. Science self-concept predicted value of science in all countries; however, the effects were stronger in Western than East Asian countries. Moreover, effects were stronger for the psychologically more proximal personal than for the more distal general value of science. Results are thus in line with the proposition that the value students attach to an academic domain in part results from a motivated process driven by their domain-specific self-concept of ability. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Scientific racism: The cloak of objectivity.
Author: Fairchild, Halford H.
Subjects: Racial and Ethnic Differences; Sociobiology; Asians; Blacks; Whites
Abstract: Reviews an application of sociobiological perspectives on 'racial' differences, focusing on the work of J. P. Rushton (e.g., see record [rid]1989-21477-001[/rid]). Rushton has concluded that, as a result of evolutionary processes, the 3 major 'racial' groups may be hierarchically ranked such that Mongoloids > Caucasoids > Negroids. The assumptions and evidence presumably supportive of Rushton's sociobiological perspective are reviewed and critiqued. It is argued that the concept of 'race' is politically defined, Darwinian arguments are teleological, theoretical constructs are flawed, and empirical databases are frequently misrepresented. This area of research is discussed in terms of the ideological underpinnings of social science inquiry and the goals and functions of scholarship in contemporary society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Selected children's representations of people in five countries.
Author: LeSourd, Sandra J.
Journal Title: Theory and Research in Social Education
Publisher: National Council for the Social Studies
Subjects: Age Differences; Child Attitudes; Cultural Sensitivity; Socioeconomic Status; Asians; Blacks; Whites; Latinos/Latinas; Childhood (birth-12 yrs); School Age (6-12 yrs); Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Abstract: Showed photos of people in 5 different countries to 24 10- and 13-yr-old children of low socioeconomic level and of Hispanic, Asian, African, Black, and White ethnic heritage and asked them open-ended questions about the photos. The questions addressed the following areas: the children's representations (RPs) of countries, the cultural information included in their RPs, the qualities of RPs associated with age, and the qualities of RPs associated with variety in children's own linguistic/cultural experience. Overall, RPs were characterized by emphasis upon austere conditions and hardships in life, and the human need for security. 10-yr-olds elaborated primarily on the thoughts and feelings of people, while 13-yr-olds included more knowledge abstracted to country level. A minor substantive difference was noted among groups differentiated by linguistic/cultural background. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Self estimates of general, crystallized, and fluid intelligences in an ethnically diverse population.
Author: Kaufman, James C.
Subjects: Ethnic Identity; Human Sex Differences; Multiple Intelligences; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Self-Report; American Indians; Arabs; Asians; Blacks; Whites; Latinos/Latinas; Fluid Intelligence; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: Self-estimated intelligence is a quick way to assess people's conceptions of their own abilities. Furnham (2001) and colleagues have used this technique to make comparisons across culture and gender and different approaches to intelligence (such as g or Multiple Intelligences). This study seeks to build on past work in two ways. First, a large,diverse sample (N = 2309) enables the study of self-estimated intelligence across ethnicity. Second, one of the most prominent accepted intelligence theories is the Cattell–Horn–Carroll (CHC) theory. Can laypeople distinguish between general, fluid, and crystallized intelligence? This study finds evidence for a 'modesty bias' in Hispanic Americans. In addition, fluid and crystallized intelligences may simply be seen as general intelligence (particularly by Caucasians and males). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Self-attention as a mediator of cultural influences on depression.
Author: Chen, Hongtu; Guarnaccia, Peter J.; Chung, Henry
Subjects: Acculturation; Attention; Cross Cultural Differences; Major Depression; Self-Monitoring; Asians; Immigration; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Thirties (30-39 yrs); Middle Age (40-64 yrs); Aged (65 yrs & older); Very Old (85 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: Background: Despite the widespread recognition of cultural differences in depressive symptoms, it is unclear through what processes culture affects depressive symptoms. Aim: This research aims at examining whether self-attention mediates the influence of acculturation on changes in depressive symptoms in an immigrant group. Method: Adults of Asian cultural backgrounds were surveyed. Depressive symptoms were assessed and divided into three categories: affective, somatic and interpersonal items of depression. Acculturation experiences were measured. Self-attention to three aspects (i.e. affective, somatic and interpersonal) of the self was also assessed. Results: As acculturation proceeds, Asian immigrants tend to pay increasingly more attention to the affective aspect of the self and less to the somatic aspect of the self. The changes in the focus of self-attention seem to explain the changes in the experience of depression that include more affective and less somatic symptoms of depression as the degree of acculturation increases. Conclusion: Self-attention to certain aspects of the self seems to play an important role mediating the influence of acculturation on changes in subcategories of depressive symptoms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Self-efficacy and HIV-related risk behaviors among multiethnic adolescents.
Author: Faryna, Ellen L.; Morales, Eduardo
Journal Title: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology
Subjects: Adolescent Attitudes; HIV; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Self-Efficacy; Asians; Blacks; Drug Abuse; Knowledge Level; Risk Taking; Sexual Risk Taking; Whites; Latinos/Latinas; Childhood (birth-12 yrs); School Age (6-12 yrs); Adolescence (13-17 yrs); Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs); Male; Female
Abstract: Investigated the self-efficacy and risk behaviors related to HIV, the comparative predictiveness of self-efficacy and knowledge, attitudes and beliefs regarding sexual activity and substance use, and possible risk profiles for HIV among adolescents. 427 high school students (aged 12–20 yrs) and attending family life education classes completed a self-administered questionnaire. Ethnic representation included African American, Chinese, Filipino, other Asian/Pacific Islander, Latino, and European American. Over half of this sample of teens were sexually active by the age of 14, with sexually active teens and substance-abusing teens scoring higher on HIV knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs regarding HIV-related behaviors. Ethnicity consistently appeared more significant in predicting these risk behaviors than gender, self-efficacy, and knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs. The predominance of ethnicity as the predictor for these HIV risk behaviors indicates that theoretical models for behavior change must include a dimension of culture, diversity, and ethnic identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Self-efficacy, parent–child relationships, and academic performance: A comparison of European American and Asian American college students.
Author: Yuan, Shu; Weiser, Dana A.; Fischer, Judith L.
Journal Title: Social Psychology of Education: An International Journal
Subjects: Academic Achievement; Cross Cultural Differences; Parent Child Relations; Self-Efficacy; Asians; College Students; Whites; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: Parent–child relationships play an important role in successful academic outcomes. Previous research suggests that the association between parent–child relationships and offspring’s academic achievement may be mediated by offspring’s self-efficacy levels, although these relationships are not fully understood. Furthermore, the association between family support and academic outcomes is well-documented among European Americans, but not across cultures. Therefore, the present study examined how parent–child relationship quality relates to young adults’ academic achievement and self-efficacy among European Americans and Asian Americans. Participants were 258 undergraduate students (85 male, 173 female) who completed a survey. Overall, both parent–child relationships and self-efficacy were significantly associated with the offspring’s academic performance, and self-efficacy mediated the relationship between parent–child relationships and school outcomes. Ethnicity moderated these relationships: among European American students, quality of parent–child relationships was not associated with self-efficacy level whereas for Asian Americans, parent–child relationships were associated with self-efficacy. These findings suggest that European American college students’ self-efficacy levels are less dependent on parent–child relationship quality, but for Asian Americans college students it may be important for educators to facilitate communication and family support so students may continue to use family as a resource for self-efficacy levels. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Self-focused attention and emotional reactivity: The role of culture.
Author: Chentsova-Dutton, Yulia E.; Tsai, Jeanne L.
Journal Title: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
Subjects: Attention; Emotional Responses; Self-Concept; Social Norms; Sociocultural Factors; Asians; Adolescence (13-17 yrs); Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs); Thirties (30-39 yrs); Male; Female
Abstract: Research conducted with European Americans suggests that attention to the individual self intensifies emotional reactivity. We propose, however, that cultural models of the self determine which aspect of the self (individual vs. relational), when attended to, intensifies emotional reactivity. In 3 studies, we predicted and observed that attention to individual aspects of the self was associated with levels of emotional reactivity that were greater in individuals from European American contexts (which promote an independent model of the self) than in individuals from Asian American contexts (which promote an interdependent model of the self). In contrast, attention to relational aspects of the self was associated with levels of emotional reactivity that were similar or greater in individuals from Asian American than in individuals from European American contexts. These findings highlight the importance of considering cultural and situational factors when examining links between the self and emotion. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Self-related beliefs and their processes: Asian insights.
Author: Chong, Wan Har; Liem, Gregory Arief D.
Subjects: Attitudes; Insight; Asians; Life Experiences
Abstract: This editorial provides an overview of the papers presented in the issue Educational Psychology. The Self serves many important functions in human growth and development. It allows the individual to form and maintain a coherent picture of one’s self as one navigates through the complex demands of the world and attempts to make sense of varied experiences. The editors believe that the articles presented in this special issue are an important step in this direction. These papers do not only represent interesting contributions to the literature in their own right but also provide an illustration of the breadth and variability of research on self-related beliefs and their processes across different Asian contexts. They have raise questions that have not been answered and highlight to us the need for greater theoretical and conceptual clarity and integration in the field, particularly as they relate to the diverse cultures across Asia. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Separation–individuation in late adolescence: An investigation of gender and ethnic differences.
Author: Gnaulati, Enrico; Heine, Barb J.
Journal Title: The Journal of Psychology: Interdisciplinary and Applied
Subjects: Human Sex Differences; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Separation Individuation; Adolescent Development; Asians; Blacks; Whites; Latinos/Latinas; Adolescence (13-17 yrs); Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: Gender and ethnic differences in separation-individuation were assessed in a sample of 125 male and 175 female undergraduates (mean age 19.56) self identified as White, African American, Hispanic, or Asian. Measures used included a demographic questionnaire and the Separation-Individuation Test of Adolescence. Except for results showing a greater tendency among the men to shun dependent ties and a superior capacity for forming close peer attachments among the women, separation-individuation development tended to be indistinguishable between the genders. Additional findings suggest that (a) Hispanics, Asians, and African Americans are more concerned with engulfment fears and needs for nurturance than Whites are; (b) Asians are more apt to shun dependent ties than Whites are; and (c) compared with Whites, African Americans anticipate rejection more and are less adept at forming close attachments with teachers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Service barriers faced by Chinese American families with a dementia relative: Perspectives from family caregivers and service professionals.
Author: Sun, Fei; Mutlu, Alisa; Coon, David
Journal Title: Clinical Gerontologist: The Journal of Aging and Mental Health
Subjects: Caregivers; Dementia; Family Members; Health Personnel; Treatment Barriers; Asians; Health Personnel Attitudes; Social Workers; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: The exponential increase in the Chinese American elder population will result in a dramatic increase in Chinese family caregivers. In spite of the projected increase, Chinese American older patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders and their family caregivers have received insufficient attention in research. This study explored service barriers perceived by family caregivers and by service professionals in a U.S. Southwest metropolitan area where there are no organized Chinese communities. Focus groups were used to obtain perceptions regarding service barriers and strategies to overcome these barriers. Content analysis was used to identify themes that were transcribed from the focus group information session. Similar to previous research, this study identified shortages of culturally-competent services, stigma, caregivers’ limited knowledge of the health care system, and lack of initiative to seek professional help as service barriers. In contrast to prior work, lack of communication concordance was identified as a major barrier in client-professional interactions, including professionals’ insufficient understanding of the Chinese language and culture, patient and family tendencies to minimize issues in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders, and incongruent expectations that health professionals and Chinese patients have for one another. Educating Chinese family members, the young generation in particular, and developing community resources for Chinese American families coping with Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders are recommended as methods to remove service barriers. Findings were further discussed within a practice-oriented framework to provide implications for gerontological practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Sex scandal science in Hong Kong.
Author: Jacobs, Katrien
Subjects: Ethnography; Mass Media; Pornography; Teaching; Asians; College Students; Politics; Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Abstract: This article gives an overview of my experience as a researcher using visual ethnography and sex studies to probe hidden strands of Chinese sex culture. More specifically, it shows how sexually explicit materials and sex studies became influential to undergraduate students at City University of Hong Kong on my course, ‘Gender Discourse’, in 2008 as a result of a celebrity sex scandal. The article considers the production and circulation of DIY pornographies made by ordinary people and attributed to celebrities by journalists, emotive and politicized reactions to pornographic media and sex scandals, and the development of teaching which encourages students to carry out creative experiments as sexually active subjects in media environments. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Sex workers, fem queens, and cross-dressers: Differential marginalizations and HIV vulnerabilities among three ethnocultural male-to-female transgender communities in New York City.
Author: Hwahng, Sel Julian; Nuttbrock, Larry
Journal Title: Sexuality Research & Social Policy: A Journal of the NSRC
Subjects: Communities; HIV; Prostitution; Sexual Risk Taking; Transsexualism; Asians; Immigration; Urban Environments
Abstract: This article describes 3 distinct ethnocultural male-to-female transgender communities in New York City: the low-income African American/Black and Latina(o) House Ball community; low-income, often undocumented immigrant Asian sex workers; and middle-class White cross-dressers. These communities are highly socially isolated from each other and are more connected to their ethnocultural contexts than to an abstract and shared transgender identity. Whereas previous research either has viewed male-to-female transgender people as one monolithic group or has separated them into abstract racial categories unconnected to their communities and lifestyles, this article positions them within specific social networks, cultures, neighborhoods, and lifestyles. With regard to HIV vulnerabilities, violence, and rape, House Ball community members seemed to engage in the riskiest form of survival sex work, whereas Asian sex workers seemed to engage in moderate-risk survival sex work. White cross-dressers seemed to engage in very low-risk recreational sex work. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Sex, contraception and contradiction among young Filipinas in Australia.
Author: Manderson, Lenore; Kelaher, Margaret; Woelz-Stirling, Nicole; Kaplan, Joy; Greene, Kirsten
Subjects: Contraceptive Devices; Cross Cultural Differences; Human Females; Psychosexual Behavior; Asians; Ethnic Values; Prevention; Sexually Transmitted Diseases; Social Values; Adolescence (13-17 yrs); Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs); Female
Abstract: Describes young women's own ideas about sex, contraception and cultural conflict. Both qualitative and quantitative data were collected from 40 Filipinas, aged 14-25 yrs, who were resident in the state of Queensland. Additionally, five focus groups were conducted with Filipina mothers concerning relationships between teenage daughters and their parents. Despite recognition of the risks of unplanned pregnancy and disease transmission, the use of contraceptives and/or prophylactics among young sexually active Filipinas in Australia is inconsistent. While this does not set them apart from Australian-born young people, sexual expression is influenced by cultural values of both the immigrant family and dominant community. Young migrant women experience particular barriers in discussing sex with their parents or other community members, because of their concern with family honour and shame and tensions related to differences in values between the host and origin cultures. Issues related to sex, contraception and the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases are rarely dealt with openly, and, as a result, young women rarely have access to practical advice about services and information. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Sexual double standards in White and Asian Americans: Ethnicity, gender, and acculturation.
Author: Guo, Yu
Subjects: Acculturation; Human Sex Differences; Psychosexual Behavior; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Sexual Attitudes; Asians; Whites; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Male; Female
Abstract: This study compares attitudes of sexual double standards (beliefs that grant more sexual freedom to men than to women) in White and Asian Americans. 506 heterosexual participants living in the U.S. (334 Whites and 172 Asians aged 18–45) answered questions assessing their attitudes towards men and women displaying various liberal sexual behaviors. Asian participants also indicated their levels of American acculturation and Asian cultural affiliation. The study found significant evidence of sexual double standards in both Whites and Asians, with certain ethnically different patterns. Whites and Asians did not differ significantly in their levels of sexual double standards when it concerned casual sexual and multiple sexual partners at the same time. However, Asians expressed stronger support for double standards than Whites when evaluating people for taking the initiative in sex and for having a large accumulated number of sexual partners. In both ethnic groups, men demonstrated stronger double standards than did women. Both Whites and Asians, regardless of gender, reported more conservative sexual attitudes for choosing marriage partners than in judging people in general. In the case of Asians, American acculturation and Asian cultural affiliation had limited and gender-specific effects on endorsement of sexual double standards. This study not only addresses an important gap in the sexual double standards literature but also brings new insights to the general discussion of ethnic differences in sexual attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Sexual positioning and race-based attraction by preferences for social dominance among gay Asian/Pacific Islander men in the United States.
Author: Tan, Judy Y.; Pratto, Felicia; Operario, Don; Dworkin, Shari L.
Subjects: Dominance Hierarchy; Male Homosexuality; Preferences; Sexual Attraction; Same Sex Intercourse; Asians; Pacific Islanders; Race and Ethnic Discrimination; Adulthood (18 yrs & older); Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs); Thirties (30-39 yrs); Middle Age (40-64 yrs); Male
Abstract: For gay men in the United States, race/ethnicity has been demonstrated to factor importantly into sexual preferences, and race-based beliefs regarding certain racial groups are prevalent within the gay male community. For gay men of color, such beliefs may differentially influence their sexual preferences. Yet, little is known about the social-psychological factors underlying differences in sexual preferences among gay men of color. The present study examined how personal preferences for social hierarchy and dominance may explain variations in sexual positioning preferences, and how this relationship may be further qualified by their race-based sexual attraction among gay Asian/Pacific Islander (API) men. A total of 141 API gay men were recruited to participate in an online survey. Measures assessed participants’ sexual positioning preferences, race-based sexual attraction, and preferences for social hierarchy or social dominance orientation (SDO). Self-identified tops scored higher on SDO than bottoms or versatiles. Participants attracted to non-API men scored higher on SDO compared to participants attracted to API men and participants who reported no race-based attraction. Finally, a significant two-way interaction indicated that tops attracted to non-API men scored the highest on SDO, and bottoms with no race-based attraction in men scored the lowest. Race/ethnicity is a prominent factor in sexual attraction and sexual positioning preferences among gay men, and one’s proclivity for social hierarchy and dominance explains differences in sexual preferences among API gay men. By demonstrating how API gay men negotiate sexual preferences, present findings help elucidate existing race-based sexual dynamics within gay male culture. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

Article Title: Shaping identities: The reading of young bilinguals.
Author: Jones, Susan
Subjects: Adolescent Development; Bilingualism; Cross Cultural Differences; Reading; Sociocultural Factors; Asians; Childhood Development; Foreign Languages; Childhood (birth-12 yrs); School Age (6-12 yrs); Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Abstract: How far do bilingual readers identify with the 'implied readers' of the texts they read?
